But also just to conversational significance in the way that we talk about an unborn child, because the Left goes to great lengths to dehumanize that unborn child in a woman's stomach, right. They say that it's a lump of cells, they say that - a CNN commentator recently said that an unborn child is not a human, right. And they do that because it's easier to abort something if you dehumanize it and you take away the fact this is a unique life living in a woman's womb. And so I think there's a shifting in the way that we converse about abortion, particularly on the heels of Ralph Northam's comments as well as the Newark law regarding third trimester abortion.

utterances.sentences: And I think Republicans should welcome these conversations.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Alright, and Law & Order: SVU is being accused of smearing the Covington High School students. In a new episode, they feature characters that look like Nick Sandmann and Congresswoman Ilhan Omar. Watch.

utterances.speaker: ARI
utterances.sentences: You're an anti-Semite!

utterances.speaker: NASAR
utterances.sentences: Stop spitting in my face like some kind of an animal.

utterances.speaker: ARI
utterances.sentences: Hey, don't you dare call me an animal.

utterances.speaker: NASAR
utterances.sentences: Did you try to rip off my hijab?

utterances.speaker: ARI
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: NASAR
utterances.sentences: You all saw, an act of aggression. No different than Israeli--

utterances.speaker: ARI
utterances.sentences: You are a liar.

utterances.speaker: NASAR
utterances.sentences: --oppression against the Palestinian people.

utterances.speaker: ARI
utterances.sentences: She's a liar.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I mean, Greg, you just saw the words right out of my mouth.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's terrible acting. I'm not sure because I have not seen this episode, whether we're watching like one of those he-said she-said things, where she's telling this story, and that didn't really happen because in reality of course it didn't happen. And maybe Law & Order is doing one of those daring switcheroos where you think it's one thing, but then it's another. If you ever want to know how deliberately misleading the media entertainment complex is, become the subject of the media entertainment complex. If you've seen the commercials for that Fox News movie - the - whatever, on Showtime, last loudest guy in the room for whatever - it's hilarious. I'm looking at it, that is not Fox News. I'm looking at it, that is not Fox News. Nobody talk--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: --and it's the caricature.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, nobody walks around talking like this. Like, oh we have to do it. Everybody's loud, everybody's talking. Russell Crowe's like this, this is what we are going to do. Nobody talks like that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Lisa, you actually saw this in real time, didn't you?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Yes, like I don't know if I should admit to that. It was on TV and then I was like this is uncanny, this is just like the Covington incident. So I kept watching, and to the police credit in the show, they do figure out that she lied about the hoax and that she called the media to come over there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: But yes, I actually watch this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, a lot of lawsuits still flying around there.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: It's a popular show, yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, first of all, Law & Order doesn't solve all the crime. I must say my wife watches incessantly, unlike Lisa. So, I get to see some of them. And to me, it's all very predictable, because they try to rip stuff out of the headlines every time. I think they've run out of story ideas.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I can give them an idea. How about Kavanaugh, that would be a good idea.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So they would probably do that. Yes so, I watch - I'm quite partial to Madame Secretary.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh okay.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And they try to - they often will have real-life scenarios. They're usually pretty responsible, except for the Cuba episode.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I agree completely.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Felicity Huffman pleading guilty in the college admissions scam. How long she could spend behind bars?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Welcome back. A big update in the college admissions scandal, actress Felicity Huffman pleading guilty in federal court today to paying $15,000 to have someone rig her daughter's SAT score. The Desperate Housewives star broke down when discussing her daughter. Prosecutors are recommending that she gets four months in prison and pay $20,000 fine. Huffman will be sentenced in September. So Greg, I'm going to start with you. So one thing I found interesting, when all this stuff broke, is the U.S. attorney saying that there should be no separate - there should be no separate admission system for the wealthy or criminal justice system, but isn't there?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think she should be executed.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, I think--

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I thought they wouldn't do it again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think everybody loves a story because it's got celebrities and you get that shot in Freud, did I say it, when people are more successful, you fall, you get happy. The one lesson here I get from it is for companies. Why don't you place more importance on schools and life experience outside the orbit of elite colleges, military experience, entrepreneurship, some other schools that aren't as important? If companies like revise their priorities on these schools and elite colleges will lose their stranglehold on parents seeking to virtue signal with inflated diplomas.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: So Dana, do you think to Greg's point, does this change the way that people view the admission system in the sense that like Americans will want more fairness in it? Because there's a Pew Research survey not too long ago basically showing that people prioritize college grades, test scores above gender or race being entered into the admissions process. So, do you think that this moves the needle in terms of people wanting a more fair system?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I do agree with Greg on that point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That even for us, like so if you have a resume that comes through, it might be a mind shift right, change the way that you think about it, there's some really great schools all across this country that are not considered elite.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't have anybody from Harvard. I actually invite them in, just so I could yell at them and take them out.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: And tell them they are not hired.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You are nothing to me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You are nothing, you are dirt.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It could be a long summer for her waiting to be sentenced in September. You can't just find somebody as punishment if you're - if it's a financial crime. She has the money to pay it, so that's not a big deal, so she is going to have to do some jail time. And then the others that pled not guilty, maybe they'll get away with it, if it goes through a jury trial. But I think the judge will be quite lenient with her.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: So, Juan, how do you think this impacts the Lori Loughlins who pled not guilty or people who have refused to plead guilty to this point, how does this impact them, what kind of pressure does it put on them?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well obviously, she's going to get the lower end of a sentence because she entered in a plea deal. She not only saved the prosecutors the time, she saved us the taxpayers the money that would - the cost of a prosecution. So I think now everybody else is in a real bind here, because if they don't plea out, they're going to get a longer sentence than what Felicity Huffman's got. I mean it's also interesting, there are a lot of interesting levels to this, William H Macy, her husband, he apparently knew about the deal, but he's not - I don't understand why he's not under any penalty here. The second thing to say is, look this system is rigged against everybody, it's particularly rigged against people of color and the poor in America, because you can see it's the legacies, it's people with big money who get into the best schools and it's supposed to be about achievement, I wish.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Tell it to the Asians. They're the ones that are getting screwed right now at Harvard.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think Asians are used as a beard (ph) by people who especially- -

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Asians are used a beard (ph).

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: --the most upper elite rich whites who want to do what we've just seen in this scandal.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Jesse, why do you think that this has gotten so much attention?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I would agree with Greg, it's a celebrity factor and people love watching other people crash and burn. But I got a look at the silver lining here, Lisa.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What is it?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Is there a silver lining?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. If you're a method actress, if you're a Felicity Huffman, doing four months in prison is the opportunity of a lifetime. Think about the character research--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: --the dialect research, the writing you could get done.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: --the meditation, the self-discovery. She can get into prison shape. She comes out of there and leverages this thing into a book deal, you get an advance. You leverage this thing into a Netflix documentary. There's a lot of money to make here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You are right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think this is a good opportunity.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to lie, before you said that, I was also thinking about a great opportunity to get in shape.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: To get in shape. Yes, the prison workout.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Greg, any parting words of wisdom?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh you came to the wrong person. It's Monday, no wisdom from me. No I think that - I'm with Jessie, she's going to - this is going to - they're going to turn lemons into lemonade. I'm afraid I just coined now.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Very good.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's going to be alright.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. Alright, One More Thing is up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Time now for One More Thing. Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: In case you were watching Game of Thrones last night, you missed one of those heart-pounding time has stopped you can't believe it moment in sports. Take a look at this video, it's the last shot in game seven the 76ers vs Raptors playoff series.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: If you ask why Leonard is the shooter, as you can see his shot from the corner bounced high off the rim four times before falling in to give the Raptors the game and the series. It took so long, emotions went up and down as the ball went up and down, and Leonard had time to squat down and wait for the outcome. As you can see the arena went crazy, but so did people outside the streets of Toronto. It was the first buzzer beater in game seven in NBA history. Jesse's hurting because he's a Sixers fan, but I got to tell you, it's been a great playoff season for hoops fans.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I didn't even know there was playoffs going on right now in basketball.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow, Lisa, even I knew that. OK, you know I'm scared to go whale watching and there's reason for that. Check this out, whale watcher Kate Cummings captured this video of a giant humpback whale leaping from the sea next to a small fishing boat. Happened out in Monterey, California. I guess it's salmon season out there, so they come to eat, they come to play and to put on a show. But I mean I'd rather watch it on video than be in that fishing boat for sure. And then, oh yes Greg--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I give props to the lower third rider for a whale of a time, very clever.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And then look at this, so there's somebody on a paddleboard. This is Rich German, he's paddling alongside a blue whale.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A rich German?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, his name is Rich German.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A rich German, I don't care if he's rich or he's a German, Dana. Please.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Anyway, obviously I would be very nervous to do that, but congratulations to them for checking that out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What's the guy's name?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Rich German. I didn't even think about that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Is he?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, I don't think so. I think he's an American.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It'd be ironic if he was.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: --Middle Class Joe.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You are next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Greg's crime corner. We were talking about Law & Order, how about law and emu?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That was so bad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Thank you. This is - emu got loose in Phoenix, Arizona, had a crime spree like you wouldn't believe. You were talking about a sex strike earlier, it went on a sex rampage, Dana. I have no idea what I'm saying, so I have no idea what to say about an emu, except that he was arrested for emulating an officer.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You turned him into that stuff you put on for your muscles.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Ooh what's that stuff called?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't know, Miracle Rub, or something.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I have no idea.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Miracle Rub?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Miracle Rub, that's something I put on--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Vladimir Putin, tremendous athlete, don't you guys agree?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He's incredible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Put on a clinic in Sochi the other day. How many goals did he score did you ask?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Eight, wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Totally legit goals, but the best part about this, skidding along, Dana, down goes Putin. What do you think happened to the guy that forgot to take the rug?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He's probably dead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He's probably dead.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Yes, he probably fell out of an apartment window this weekend.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know, you're probably not going to make it through the night Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What did I say this time?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm just saying he has people in America.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh really?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, they're working for Hillary.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh no, we had to get Russians here somewhere. Lisa?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Ask Christopher Steele. All right, well it was a snowmencement (ph) to remember, get it. I think there's a video we got to show, yes there we go. All right, so that's at University of Colorado, Boulder students. They were unfazed even though the snow came tumbling down. Many of them accessorized their caps and gowns with ski goggles. But the best part came when they started pummeling each other with snowballs and celebrated this big achievement with a snowball fight.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's why they wear goggles.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's what you call global warming, Lisa.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I think it was like a lot of fun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It snows in May.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Snowball fights are the best.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: There's nearly 9,000 students that hurled snowballs at each other.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't understand why they didn't move it indoors. But on the other hand--

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: That's more fun.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well it's fun, but it's snow in May.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's also Colorado. And I remember just a few years ago, it snowed on Memorial Day weekend in Colorado.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know, that's a great story.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Thank you. I always love to end with a bang. Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" is up next. Content and Programming Copyright 2019 Fox News Network, LLC. utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. Along with Lisa Boothe, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City. And this is "The Five." Brand-new headaches for Democrats heading into 2020. Freshman Congresswoman Rashida Tlaib creating a new controversy over her comments about the Holocaust while discussing the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

utterances.speaker: REP. RASHIDA TLAIB (D-MI)
utterances.utterance: This is kind of a calming feeling that I tell folks when I think of the Holocaust and the tragedy of the Holocaust and the fact that it was my ancestors. Palestinians who lost their land and some lost their lives, their livelihood, the human dignity. Their existence in many ways had been wiped out and some people passed. I mean, just all of it was in the name of trying to create a safe haven for Jews.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: President Trump and Republicans are slamming Tlaib as anti-Semitic and want Nancy Pelosi to take action against the congresswoman, but Tlaib is refusing to back down. She is responding by saying critics are twisting her words in an effort to silence her. And Pelosi tweeting "Republicans desperate attempts to smear Rashida Tlaib and misrepresent her comments are outrageous. President Trump and House GOP should apologize to Representative Tlaib and the American people for their gross misrepresentation." So, we'll take this around the table. Greg, do you think the Republicans hit the mark here or maybe a mistake?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: You know, this is terrible for a Monday, because you are forcing me after a calm week that I have to defend this lady.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. Here we go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. So, I'll going to defend her and then I'm going to criticize her.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: First of all, the outrage over the Holocaust phrasing is distracting from her actual legitimate mistake about history. She did not find the Holocaust calming, she said she found the idea of Palestinians providing safe haven to be calming. So, this is no different than the fine hoax myth where people thought that Trump was talking about white supremacist and Antifa when he was actually talking about the debate over the monument. So that's wrong. They are misinterpreting her; they're taking it out of context and we should all have sympathy for her because people do that to us on THE FIVE all the time. They will take something we say whether it's a joke, and then they'll put it on a blog and say Jesse says everybody should die. And you were talking about your hair, that you dye your hair. So that --

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Fake news.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That outrage is displaced. It's misplaced. But her claim that the Palestinians were open arms about this, that's a troubling part. I'm not a historian. I don't know enough about this, but I read up on it. I mean, the Palestinian leaders were collaborating with Hitler. Right? They prevented safe haven for a lot of people who ended up dead. So, her history is what is the outrage, the Republican should focus on that and not about pulling it out of context thing, the calming word which is kind of cheap.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Which gave her an opportunity to say at least --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- in her words were taken out of context.

utterances.speaker: LISA BOOTHE, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: But I think part of the reason is that she doesn't really deserve the benefit of the doubt. And the reason she doesn't deserve the benefit of the doubt is it's not that, it's not just the words that she chooses to use that are under scrutiny, it's also the policies that she chooses to support. She supports a one-state solution, she's also been called out by members of her own party for supporting the boycott Divestment and Sanctions movement which Jerry Nadler, chairman of the judiciary committee and Bradley Schneider said that basically is asking for the elimination of Israel. So, it's not just the words that she is using, it's her policies that she supports. And if you want to look at an area where the Democratic Party is deeply divided it's on the issue of Israel. I mean, remember Steny Hoyer going to the AIPAC's stage and calling out Omar and Tlaib, and these freshman members of Congress and their progressive viewpoints that many views as anti-Semitic.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There was an opportunity, Juan, for the House Democrats to pass in anti-Semitism resolution. They decided not to do that. Let me read to you President Trump's tweet about this. He said "Democrat Representative Tlaib is being slammed for her horrible and highly insensitive statement on the Holocaust. She obviously has tremendous hatred of Israel and the Jewish people. Can you imagine what would happen if I ever said what she said and says?"

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: You know, I'm just -- I'm just flummoxed about this, it seems to me, we talked Tlaib creating controversy. It seems to me the Republicans are creating controversy and President Trump is taking the lead, because he sees some political advantage in this and trying to portray and smear her as somehow anti- Semitic. I mean, we can have arguments about the history, totally legitimate, but I, you know, I just take my hat off, Greg. Exactly right. This woman was talking about the potential bond between Palestinians and Jews something you almost never hear about. Because she said in fact, who had to give up their land not voluntarily. She made that very clear not voluntarily, but people who gave up land to create the safe haven that is Israel for Jews post-Holocaust. That's what she said, and yet, here we are back to the same all refrain that somehow the first Palestinian-American in the Congress along with a woman who has come from Somalia or Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a Latina woman, women of color somehow demonized here conveniently, not only by Trump but by the number two and number three Republicans in the House again for a political advantage. To me, I just -- I think that this is excessive. I don't think this is right. I don't understand how it's going on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But it's not just them. I mean, I learned my history today from all places, CNN. I mean, CNN, John King took her to task with historians. That's where I am. I'm going like, it was a big -- her history was wrong, but anyway.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And then but she -- but because of this, so this is what she tweeted, Jesse. "Policing my words, twisting and turning them to ignite vile attacks on me will not work. All of you who are trying to silence me will fail miserably. I will never allow you to take my words out of context too push a racist and hateful agenda. The truth will always win." And what I think about that is the truth on the history side, that's where -- that's where the truth should lie.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. Well, someone very smart one time told me never to invoke the Holocaust unless you absolutely have to, because you never want to use in an analogy, you never want to compare your political opponents to Hitler or to Nazis. And you definitely don't want to compare the suffering of Jews during the Holocaust to the suffering of any other people. And she kind of almost did that in a way. So, the facts that Jesse Watters is giving us advice to anybody else on how not to be offensive, let that sink in, Representative Tlaib, because we've come a long way. But looking at the context of what she said, she was more clumsy than she was anti-Semitic. But there was a little anti-Semitism strain in there. And that's about revising the history of the Holocaust. And it is a slippery slope, because when you talk about what Greg said, the Palestinian leadership did not welcome --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what she said.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- the resettlement of the Jews with open arms.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what she said, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They met with Adolf Hitler. They sided with Adolf Hitler. And then since that time period the Palestinians and the entire Arab world has tried to exterminate the Jewish people. If you look at anything that anybody has said in Iran and Iraq and Saudi Arabia. That's their entire agenda. That's what people have trouble with. Whitewashing history and then when she is attacked for it saying, you know, I will not be silenced.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Can I add just for the bigger thing, because this happens a lot. We see this the Republicans will strongman an argument after the Democrat strongman an argument when they hear a quote by somebody on THE FIVE. Right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A great quote, by the way.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. And then you go you seek the worst possible interpretation of a quote. This is the contagion that the media has infected the world with, which is that when you say something, I'm going to think that it's the worst. The left does it to us and we do it to them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And the Washington Post who actually defended her here is guilty of the exact same thing that Republicans do all the time, and now they are on their high horse talking about context?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: But it's also --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They always remove context when they attack Republicans.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: But it's also beyond just the statement alone, as I mention before. You have Democrats on her side of the aisle calling her out for the policies that she supports. The Zionist Organization of America recently called on the Democratic Party to kick her out, kick her off committees. They named terrorist -- like terrorists and sympathizers that she associates herself with, so I think this is much deeper than just a simple comment.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, you are going to -- so in other words --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I'm talking this is what the Zionist Organization of America said.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. But you want to put it in a box and say everybody is this way or that way. And you are with the Zionists. And the Zionist that have been taken --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Well, do you support the BDS movement?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Are you kidding me? No, I don't. But I'm trying to say --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Well, there you go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- you can't trust the Zionists to go after Tlaib.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: BDS.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is -- but again, I'm sure that morning newspapers will say, well, President Trump tweeted about, so we got to say Representative Tlaib creates the controversy. No, Trump created the controversy --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: She also sorted out --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- and the Republicans have made --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But you just did the same thing you are accusing her of.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I am not. No, I'm not.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It doesn't have to -- you don't have to have two polarizing positions.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But it is in this situation. I know we all sat here and said the woman was taken out of context.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: And she was --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, she was sloppy and she got taken to the woodshed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's all it is.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, and that was our a-block.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Bill Nye, the Science Guy attacking Republicans with a foul- mouthed to defend climate change. I was shocked.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Were you?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We'll show you next.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: All right. We got one more speaker.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Democrats holding climate change rallies today like this one where New York Mayor Bill de Blasio was heckled inside Trump tower. Meanwhile, Bill Nye, the Science Guy, taking a shot at Republicans for not supporting the Green New Deal.

utterances.speaker: BILL NYE, TV PRESENTER
utterances.utterance: What I am saying is the planet is on (muted) fire. There are a lot of things we can do to put it out. Are any of them free? No, of course not, nothing is free, you idiots. Grow the (muted) up. You're not children anymore. I didn't mind explaining photosynthesis to you when you were 12, but you are adults now. This is an actual crisis. Got it? Safety glasses off (muted).

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow. I've never seen him like that. Jesse, what do you make of it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Desperate.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- if it was a real crisis, he wouldn't be joking like that. The whole global warming hysteria is the perfect encapsulation of the Democratic Party.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I love this picture of you with the fire extinguisher.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. I'm going to use it on you, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm on a fire.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'll tell you what.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm on fire.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because it hits both nerve centers in the party. Their psychological problems, and their policy priorities. Because, one, it makes them feel superior to other people, it makes them feel like they are saving the world even though they are really not. And it also makes them feel like they are in touch with nature even though they are the ones that live in the cities and it's the conservatives doing the hunting and the fishing in the agricultural and rural America. In terms of policy they just make people feel guilty and use fear in order to do what they need to do. Because if you think about it all of their solutions to everything is the same. Global warming hysteria is just the Trojan horse to get in to all the things they want to do. Regulations, tax hikes, ridiculous amounts of spending and attacking oil and gas companies, because this is all about feeling guilty for the success of capitalism. They can't control capitalism and that drives them crazy. So, the Green New Deal just gives them the opportunity to control capitalism.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, thank you for your --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You are welcome.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We love hearing from Richie Rich and the plutocrats on this show. Lisa --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I am the lowest paid guy here. Yes, you probably are.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me ask Lisa. When you see something like Bill Nye go wild like that or you hear about all these rallies today, they had a big one in Washington at Howard University, it makes me think the Democrats see political advantage in talking about the Green New Deal, climate change and the like. Republicans don't see an advantage, you just heard from Jesse, but they don't have any plan, what do you make of that?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Well, I would say Democrats are dumb if that's the assumption that they're making. If you look at something like the Green New Deal it's going to be detrimental in states like the rustbelt states. I would say for Republicans the irony of this, is if you look at part of the reason why we've been leading the world in reducing carbon emissions is because of innovations and things like natural gas vis the private sector. Yet, what Democrats want to do is move us entirely off of fossil fuels which mind you, it makes up, you know, over 80 percent of the United States energy consumption. But pertaining to the rustbelt states, like, have fun going out to Michigan, Wisconsin and talking about how you're essentially going to get jobs there, jack up energy prices which mind you, disproportionately impacts lower income Americans. So much so what you got union groups like AFL-CIO putting out statements condemning the Green New Deal and talking about the fact that it's a threat to jobs, a threat to families in the way that they live their life. So, you know what, if Democrats think this is a good idea, like, be my guest, have fun with it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. So, let's take a look at this. Remember when Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez said this?

utterances.speaker: REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ (D-NY)
utterances.utterance: How many years until the world ends again? We have 12 years left to cut emissions by at least 50 percent, if not more. And for everyone who wants to make a joke about that, you may laugh, but your grandkids will not.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The congresswoman now saying those comments were, quote, "dry humor," she said that she was being sarcastic. Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, it's funny. Actually -- so they always say that about President Trump as well.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right? So, they always say, he'll say that the president will say that obviously was a joke. And they make fun of him for it. So, I actually think wasn't it in the Green New Deal documents that it was post on the web site --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- hat it was 12 years? So, ha, ha, hilarious. I do -- the Green New Deal rallies, I think that's pretty interesting. I don't understand the day or the significance, and of course, like we could use all global warming. kidding. I know you guys hate that when we all say that. But I do think that's pretty interesting. I sent an article to Greg yesterday, because I couldn't believe it. On the same weekend that they are doing Green New Deal stuff, in Illinois they are planning to introduce a bill into the legislature to tax people that bought an electric vehicle $1,000 apiece per year. Guess why? Because they are not buying gas. So that means that they are not paying into the gas tax but they are still on the roads. So, it's really like an anti-carbon tax.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hilarious.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That is why the circular argument gets frustrating for conservatives.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And guess what? We also have Jay Inslee, other Democratic candidate, Greg, he's out on a motor scooter and saying, you know, this could be the future. You have Joe Biden saying there are ways that you can look at this that won't alienate anybody because we rejoin the Paris deal. There is Inslee on a scooter. You know, that there is a middle ground for conservatives.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There is a huge middle ground, and we're in it right now. You see people from the Sierra Club, you see Bill Gates, they are right there. It's called nuclear power. It's the cleanest, safest, more environmentally -- most environmentally friendly type of energy that we have right now. And whether you like it or not, that's going to solve climate change. I want to make two points. A couple of things bug me about, you know, nuclear energy has a bad rap because it's always been associated to the bomb. Right? The nuclear bomb.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And accident.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, renewables, where the accidents are few. And the solution --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But that's why they gave it a best.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, the research shows, anyway. Renewable energy is somehow immune to a serious environmental reporting. When was the last time anybody read an article about solar power waste? OK? Solar panels create a ton of waste. By 2050 there's going to be like 70 million metric tons, and this stuff is difficult to recycle and it contains toxic chemicals like cadmium which can leak out into the soil and the water.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Cadmium?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Cadmium. So, what I am saying is no one talks about this, but this is going to blow your mind. Do you remember when there would be an oil spill and they would show the little ducks and everybody felt bad, because they were cleaning the little ducks, have you ever seen any footage from any photographers on the millions in billions of large and rare birds that have been murdered by wind farms? Wind farms are now the leading, probably one of the leading predators of birds, second to cats, I believe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Bird murderers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So where -- OK, so where is PETA? Where is PETA? Where is Audubon Society? Where are all the green groups? Where are the bird watchers? Are they all bought for and paid for by PETA? I don't know. Or by the green groups? The point is, we used to see these oil spills, we don't see the dead birds, that tells you something about the media. I don't know what --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Where's the justice? Where's the justice for the birds?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. The fact --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: It's a great point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's actually -- it's actually millions of large birds.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And actually, under the Migratory Treaty Act companies that if you are responsible -- you can get responsible for it, you actually are fined.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, they blame the companies, but nobody talks about the actual birds.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, there is so much roast chicken available.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm still in my lawn.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The migratory birds --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's talking about Eagles, and he's talking about Condors.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is going into the weeds about birds and the like.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Save the birds.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You don't care about the birds, Juan, great. Good for you, Juan. You're going to get the letters.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Republicans have no ideas for dealing with climate change.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I just gave you one, nuclear power. Listen, Juan. You got to listen.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Zero. All right. An author could --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: An exit in segment with B.S.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, that's what you gave us. All right. An author could --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nuclear power is not B.S. Do your research.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- over a backlash. Greg's take on the latest social media mob attack as he calls it, that's next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Done.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. This next story contains everything I hate about modern life, callout culture, company cowardice, and people eating on subways. So, writer Natasha Tynes, I call her fink, tweeted a photo of a D.C. subway employee eating on a train and then reported her to her metro bosses saying, quote, "I thought we were not allowed to eat on the train. This is unacceptable." What a narc. Transit officials thanked her, but of course, social media backlash ensued. And I get it. Even though eating on a train is banned, no one likes a tattletale. But then the writer's publisher a book company halted printing of the lady's book citing her thinking on a black worker. Now did you see new variable? Yes. If things weren't already a barrel of nonsense, the outrage addicted media had to add race to this mix. So, California cold-blood books who stop the printing say they hope Natasha learns that black women feel the effects of systematic racism the most. So, there it is. Everything that makes the present day a drag, all wrapped into one story. Annoying busybodies who use Twitter to exercise power, government employees breaking rules we got to follow, and of course, knee- jerk instantaneous calls of racism. The only thing that could make the story more annoying and more depressing and more stupid as if somehow the producers here work Maroon 5 into it. Well done. Well done. All right, Dana, I don't think the story needed a racial component, but why not throw one in, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, I was like, if I am trying to think, I am on the subway a lot.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You do.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You see a lot of things on a subway, but I'm not the boss of those people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's not --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's not my place to say you are not supposed to bring your bike on the subway.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I hate narcs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because may be that guy really has to get to his next job, or like, what if you have the dog on the subway.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And what if you eat on the subway because you are working through shifts.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Starving. I have eaten a bagel on the subway.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, that's gross. But no. You know, she might have two jobs, her kid might be sick. You don't know what's going on in her life, Jesse. I argue though that the writer wasn't racist, because she didn't notice the workers race, or else she wouldn't have done it, because she knew that she would have gotten in trouble.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Here's why I like the story. You can see what hand beats another hand in identity politics poker.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's funny.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, you have right here a black female --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Government.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- Republican union employee.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She, her hand beats a female Muslim Republican immigrant author.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She was Muslim?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I didn't know that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I researched it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, yes. She is a Jordanian immigrant.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, but that's not what this is about. This is snitches get stitches.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is what that's about. And I have rules for stitching.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do you?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There's only three times it's acceptable. One, snitching on a sibling.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Two, snitching on the deep state, that's called whistle-blowing. And three, if you are paid to snitch like if you are videotaping or truck idling in Manhattan (Inaudible) thought of thee fine. But here is the real story.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Terrible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This woman was not shucking corn. She like had a contained package and a sandwich. It was neat and tidy, there is no reason to do anything about it. The bigger story is the publishing company.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They could have capitalized on this thing. This woman has created an amazing controversy with race and class and social media and they fired her instead of I don't know, giving her a three-book deal. They can have her on NPR, The View. They can arrange a sit down --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You are so backwards.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- with the author and the victim.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You are so backwards. That makes no sense.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You know, just to take identity politics a step further --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- do you know who would have gotten a three-book deal if they had done that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Who?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: An older white male.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Kidding.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's OK. I think that was right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Of course, you would, Juan, because you have white males.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, too many villains in this story, I think. WILLIAMS: True. But I tell you what, I don't like people eating on the subway. I think it's wrong. I think it's against the rules. When I saw Dana eating that bagel, I sent a picture to our boss. Do I get the black man kind of response?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You got a corner office out of it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, but here's the thing. Here's the over-response, we know from THE FIVE, this program, that in fact the people who are on Twitter is a very small group.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's not representative of most Americans--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's not the reaction most people are having.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: These are people who I think are bored and looking for something to get upset about, and they did in this case. I think the woman was out of control in terms of trying to get the woman fired and get her to trouble. OK, but do I like eating on subways? No. And do I like employees breaking rules at the job? No. But to me, the real - the reality here is Twitter out of control, and we just deal with this now, it's part of our lives. Unfortunately, everybody's tweeting on social media.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But the thing is - this is another case where Twitter cost somebody a job. And Twitter is free, you're not getting paid to do Twitter- -

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But you can lose your money.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I was also going to say it's not just Twitter out of control, it's also these companies allowing themselves to be held hostage by Twitter and people on Twitter, right. Like the idea that somehow racism had anything to do with this is utterly insane. The writer, as Jesse pointed out, calls herself a minority writer. And I also think right now with throwing around charges of racism so cavalierly, you actually devalue the term and the accusation, right, so I guess everyone's a racist, if you call someone a racist, that loses its potency. So I think all of this is just dumb. But I will say, I used to live in DC and rode the DC Metro, and you don't want people eating on it because that's how you get rats and it gets gross, and then it's just stinky, like the New York subway.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what I think--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I hate the rats.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think we're short though on empathy. She had no empathy for that woman as a worker.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Also she didn't give it much thought.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Sitting casually like taking a picture, you are bored, you're like tweeting and saying--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I hate - I have to say I hate the writers. She's like somebody - nobody wants to eat on the subway unless they have to.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So obviously she had to eat because she had to get somewhere. And this lady - I think the lady approached her and said like you can't do that and she said mind your own business, which is the--

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I love it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I think she needs to write more and spend time doing other things.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, I think she will have free time to write more. Publishing is the next big thing - what's her name again - Natasha. All right, Hollywood's boycott over Georgia's new abortion law could be backfiring. And a new smear against the Covington students, that's next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hollywood lashing out against conservatives. Liberals lining up to demand a boycott on filming in Georgia over the state's Heartbeat abortion law, but their plan's already starting to fizzle out. Actors and some small production companies say they won't work in the state, but big studios aren't budging. And Alyssa Milano is being mocked for taking things a little step farther. The actress actually called for a sex strike to protest Georgia's abortion law. Greg, I don't think women understand the power they have with the sex strike thing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes they do, why do you think she's--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know, but I mean if this didn't caught on, I honestly think if the right people had a sex strike, we could do the - sign the trade deal next week.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK, this is a very, very old idea, it's based on a play, and I think I've seen it in a movie where they try to get people to quit smoking by not having sex. The best - but this is misogyny actually because Alyssa Milano is demanding women to forfeit their own choice to engage in a pleasurable behavior under the assumption, and get this, under the assumption that sex is a reward for men, not fun or rewarding for women. So, it's actually an incredibly old-fashioned point of view.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So you are saying men should throw a sex strike?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You think that would--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I do that when I go bowling.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You think that will solve the China trade deal?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Count me out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, Dana, what do you think is going on down there in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well I think that The Devil Went Down to Georgia.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Her name is Alyssa Milano.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Here's the thing I would say to states. You don't need these guys, you don't need to - you don't need to bend over backwards to invite the movie industry into your state. The best way to get people to move to your state is to cut taxes, streamline your regulations, have good law and order, and good schools. That's it. And then you don't have to have these shenanigans and these people threatening you because your state legislature passed a bill that was representative of what the constituents asked for.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And these boycotts don't work. Even one of the Democrats in the state said I have constituents, Juan, who benefit from the film industry in Georgia. Instead of boycotting, let's just take back the House and the Senate in the next election.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That makes sense. But I think what you're seeing here, I've said before, is an effort by people in the pro-life movement to circumvent roe v wade with these Heartbeat laws that are now in so many state legislatures. I think you're up to six or so. But the point to me is boycotts are American tradition. We know this wide and far. We just saw one when people were saying oh these NFL players, why they kneel, let's not watch the NFL for a while. Well it worked for a while, but that's their right, they can watch what they want or not watch. And people who want to say that they really don't like the fact that a woman's right to choose is being so politicized in these southern states for the most part, you know what, they have a right to also say this is wrong. So let them go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Lisa?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Well, I think we have a lot of pro lifers applauding Alyssa Milano because it's less people that would be apt to have abortions that are going to be having children and getting pregnant. But I'll say one thing that's interesting about the Heartbeat Law to me is that it gives full legal rights to unborn children, right. And so obviously there's a legal significance to that. But also just to conversational significance in the way that we talk about an unborn child, because the Left goes to great lengths to dehumanize that unborn child in a woman's stomach, right. They say that it's a lump of cells, they say that - a CNN commentator recently said that an unborn child is not a human, right. And they do that because it's easier to abort something if you dehumanize it and you take away the fact this is a unique life living in a woman's womb. And so I think there's a shifting in the way that we converse about abortion, particularly on the heels of Ralph Northam's comments as well as the Newark law regarding third trimester abortion.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: And I think Republicans should welcome these conversations.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Alright, and Law & Order: SVU is being accused of smearing the Covington High School students. In a new episode, they feature characters that look like Nick Sandmann and Congresswoman Ilhan Omar. Watch.

utterances.speaker: ARI
utterances.utterance: You're an anti-Semite!

utterances.speaker: NASAR
utterances.utterance: Stop spitting in my face like some kind of an animal.

utterances.speaker: ARI
utterances.utterance: Hey, don't you dare call me an animal.

utterances.speaker: NASAR
utterances.utterance: Did you try to rip off my hijab?

utterances.speaker: ARI
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: NASAR
utterances.utterance: You all saw, an act of aggression. No different than Israeli--

utterances.speaker: ARI
utterances.utterance: You are a liar.

utterances.speaker: NASAR
utterances.utterance: --oppression against the Palestinian people.

utterances.speaker: ARI
utterances.utterance: She's a liar.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, Greg, you just saw the words right out of my mouth.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's terrible acting. I'm not sure because I have not seen this episode, whether we're watching like one of those he-said she-said things, where she's telling this story, and that didn't really happen because in reality of course it didn't happen. And maybe Law & Order is doing one of those daring switcheroos where you think it's one thing, but then it's another. If you ever want to know how deliberately misleading the media entertainment complex is, become the subject of the media entertainment complex. If you've seen the commercials for that Fox News movie - the - whatever, on Showtime, last loudest guy in the room for whatever - it's hilarious. I'm looking at it, that is not Fox News. I'm looking at it, that is not Fox News. Nobody talk--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: --and it's the caricature.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, nobody walks around talking like this. Like, oh we have to do it. Everybody's loud, everybody's talking. Russell Crowe's like this, this is what we are going to do. Nobody talks like that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Lisa, you actually saw this in real time, didn't you?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Yes, like I don't know if I should admit to that. It was on TV and then I was like this is uncanny, this is just like the Covington incident. So I kept watching, and to the police credit in the show, they do figure out that she lied about the hoax and that she called the media to come over there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: But yes, I actually watch this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, a lot of lawsuits still flying around there.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: It's a popular show, yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, first of all, Law & Order doesn't solve all the crime. I must say my wife watches incessantly, unlike Lisa. So, I get to see some of them. And to me, it's all very predictable, because they try to rip stuff out of the headlines every time. I think they've run out of story ideas.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I can give them an idea. How about Kavanaugh, that would be a good idea.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So they would probably do that. Yes so, I watch - I'm quite partial to Madame Secretary.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh okay.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And they try to - they often will have real-life scenarios. They're usually pretty responsible, except for the Cuba episode.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I agree completely.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Felicity Huffman pleading guilty in the college admissions scam. How long she could spend behind bars?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. A big update in the college admissions scandal, actress Felicity Huffman pleading guilty in federal court today to paying $15,000 to have someone rig her daughter's SAT score. The Desperate Housewives star broke down when discussing her daughter. Prosecutors are recommending that she gets four months in prison and pay $20,000 fine. Huffman will be sentenced in September. So Greg, I'm going to start with you. So one thing I found interesting, when all this stuff broke, is the U.S. attorney saying that there should be no separate - there should be no separate admission system for the wealthy or criminal justice system, but isn't there?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think she should be executed.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I think--

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I thought they wouldn't do it again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think everybody loves a story because it's got celebrities and you get that shot in Freud, did I say it, when people are more successful, you fall, you get happy. The one lesson here I get from it is for companies. Why don't you place more importance on schools and life experience outside the orbit of elite colleges, military experience, entrepreneurship, some other schools that aren't as important? If companies like revise their priorities on these schools and elite colleges will lose their stranglehold on parents seeking to virtue signal with inflated diplomas.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: So Dana, do you think to Greg's point, does this change the way that people view the admission system in the sense that like Americans will want more fairness in it? Because there's a Pew Research survey not too long ago basically showing that people prioritize college grades, test scores above gender or race being entered into the admissions process. So, do you think that this moves the needle in terms of people wanting a more fair system?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I do agree with Greg on that point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That even for us, like so if you have a resume that comes through, it might be a mind shift right, change the way that you think about it, there's some really great schools all across this country that are not considered elite.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't have anybody from Harvard. I actually invite them in, just so I could yell at them and take them out.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: And tell them they are not hired.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You are nothing to me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You are nothing, you are dirt.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It could be a long summer for her waiting to be sentenced in September. You can't just find somebody as punishment if you're - if it's a financial crime. She has the money to pay it, so that's not a big deal, so she is going to have to do some jail time. And then the others that pled not guilty, maybe they'll get away with it, if it goes through a jury trial. But I think the judge will be quite lenient with her.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: So, Juan, how do you think this impacts the Lori Loughlins who pled not guilty or people who have refused to plead guilty to this point, how does this impact them, what kind of pressure does it put on them?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well obviously, she's going to get the lower end of a sentence because she entered in a plea deal. She not only saved the prosecutors the time, she saved us the taxpayers the money that would - the cost of a prosecution. So I think now everybody else is in a real bind here, because if they don't plea out, they're going to get a longer sentence than what Felicity Huffman's got. I mean it's also interesting, there are a lot of interesting levels to this, William H Macy, her husband, he apparently knew about the deal, but he's not - I don't understand why he's not under any penalty here. The second thing to say is, look this system is rigged against everybody, it's particularly rigged against people of color and the poor in America, because you can see it's the legacies, it's people with big money who get into the best schools and it's supposed to be about achievement, I wish.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tell it to the Asians. They're the ones that are getting screwed right now at Harvard.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think Asians are used as a beard (ph) by people who especially- -

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Asians are used a beard (ph).

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: --the most upper elite rich whites who want to do what we've just seen in this scandal.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Jesse, why do you think that this has gotten so much attention?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I would agree with Greg, it's a celebrity factor and people love watching other people crash and burn. But I got a look at the silver lining here, Lisa.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What is it?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Is there a silver lining?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. If you're a method actress, if you're a Felicity Huffman, doing four months in prison is the opportunity of a lifetime. Think about the character research--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: --the dialect research, the writing you could get done.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: --the meditation, the self-discovery. She can get into prison shape. She comes out of there and leverages this thing into a book deal, you get an advance. You leverage this thing into a Netflix documentary. There's a lot of money to make here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You are right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think this is a good opportunity.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to lie, before you said that, I was also thinking about a great opportunity to get in shape.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: To get in shape. Yes, the prison workout.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Greg, any parting words of wisdom?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh you came to the wrong person. It's Monday, no wisdom from me. No I think that - I'm with Jessie, she's going to - this is going to - they're going to turn lemons into lemonade. I'm afraid I just coined now.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Very good.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's going to be alright.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Alright, One More Thing is up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Time now for One More Thing. Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In case you were watching Game of Thrones last night, you missed one of those heart-pounding time has stopped you can't believe it moment in sports. Take a look at this video, it's the last shot in game seven the 76ers vs Raptors playoff series.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: If you ask why Leonard is the shooter, as you can see his shot from the corner bounced high off the rim four times before falling in to give the Raptors the game and the series. It took so long, emotions went up and down as the ball went up and down, and Leonard had time to squat down and wait for the outcome. As you can see the arena went crazy, but so did people outside the streets of Toronto. It was the first buzzer beater in game seven in NBA history. Jesse's hurting because he's a Sixers fan, but I got to tell you, it's been a great playoff season for hoops fans.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I didn't even know there was playoffs going on right now in basketball.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow, Lisa, even I knew that. OK, you know I'm scared to go whale watching and there's reason for that. Check this out, whale watcher Kate Cummings captured this video of a giant humpback whale leaping from the sea next to a small fishing boat. Happened out in Monterey, California. I guess it's salmon season out there, so they come to eat, they come to play and to put on a show. But I mean I'd rather watch it on video than be in that fishing boat for sure. And then, oh yes Greg--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I give props to the lower third rider for a whale of a time, very clever.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And then look at this, so there's somebody on a paddleboard. This is Rich German, he's paddling alongside a blue whale.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A rich German?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, his name is Rich German.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A rich German, I don't care if he's rich or he's a German, Dana. Please.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Anyway, obviously I would be very nervous to do that, but congratulations to them for checking that out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What's the guy's name?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Rich German. I didn't even think about that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is he?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I don't think so. I think he's an American.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It'd be ironic if he was.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: --Middle Class Joe.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You are next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Greg's crime corner. We were talking about Law & Order, how about law and emu?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was so bad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you. This is - emu got loose in Phoenix, Arizona, had a crime spree like you wouldn't believe. You were talking about a sex strike earlier, it went on a sex rampage, Dana. I have no idea what I'm saying, so I have no idea what to say about an emu, except that he was arrested for emulating an officer.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You turned him into that stuff you put on for your muscles.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Ooh what's that stuff called?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know, Miracle Rub, or something.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I have no idea.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Miracle Rub?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Miracle Rub, that's something I put on--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Vladimir Putin, tremendous athlete, don't you guys agree?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He's incredible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Put on a clinic in Sochi the other day. How many goals did he score did you ask?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Eight, wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Totally legit goals, but the best part about this, skidding along, Dana, down goes Putin. What do you think happened to the guy that forgot to take the rug?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He's probably dead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's probably dead.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Yes, he probably fell out of an apartment window this weekend.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, you're probably not going to make it through the night Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What did I say this time?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm just saying he has people in America.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh really?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, they're working for Hillary.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh no, we had to get Russians here somewhere. Lisa?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Ask Christopher Steele. All right, well it was a snowmencement (ph) to remember, get it. I think there's a video we got to show, yes there we go. All right, so that's at University of Colorado, Boulder students. They were unfazed even though the snow came tumbling down. Many of them accessorized their caps and gowns with ski goggles. But the best part came when they started pummeling each other with snowballs and celebrated this big achievement with a snowball fight.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's why they wear goggles.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's what you call global warming, Lisa.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: I think it was like a lot of fun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It snows in May.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: Snowball fights are the best.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: There's nearly 9,000 students that hurled snowballs at each other.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't understand why they didn't move it indoors. But on the other hand--

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.utterance: That's more fun.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well it's fun, but it's snow in May.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's also Colorado. And I remember just a few years ago, it snowed on Memorial Day weekend in Colorado.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, that's a great story.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Thank you. I always love to end with a bang. Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" is up next. Content and Programming Copyright 2019 Fox News Network, LLC.
